packageinfo.description: Sybase/SQL Server Database Driver from Adobe

methodinfo.longdescription: ColdFusion is forced to compile a page. This could mean the server is recently started, or that the template cache size is too small for the number of pages and CFCs in your application.

methodinfo.description: Waiting for response from database server
Waiting for data from network connection
Waiting for new inbound TCP connections
Waiting for an object lock to release
methodinfo.longdescription: This object is waiting for another a certain period of time to elapse, or another object to notify it to proceed. Usually, this can be ignored; if this is being called directly by your application code, this indicate a bottleneck.

methodinfo.description: Waiting for a page request from the Web server
methodinfo.longdescription:
If you're seeing this issue for active threads, then these are the likely causes:

  1. There's a network issue preventing packets from getting through;
  2. Something went horribly wrong with the Web server plug-in;
  3. The Web server plug-in is a different version than the JRun server, and this is interfering with communications.

Things to try:

  1. Use the "wsconfig" tool in \jrun4\bin or \cfusionmx\runtime\bin to uninstall and reinstall the Web server plug-in;
  2. Increase the TCP receive buffer window size to improve the efficiency of web server to JRun server communications (see http://cfprimer.blogspot.com/2005/03/tcpip-efficiency.html);
  3. If you can reproduce this, use a tool such as Ethereal to capture the communications around the time that things go bad, and send that trace file to us or Adobe Product Support (or both!) for analysis.

methodinfo.description: Fetching CGI header from Web server
methodinfo.longdescription:
If you're seeing this issue for many or all threads, then these are the likely causes:

  1. There's a network issue preventing packets from getting through;
  2. Something went horribly wrong with the Web server plug-in;
  3. The Web server plug-in is a different version than the JRun server, and this is interfering with communications.

Things to try:

  1. Use the "wsconfig" tool in \jrun4\bin or \cfusionmx\runtime\bin to uninstall and reinstall the Web server plug-in;
  2. Increase the TCP receive buffer window size to improve the efficiency of web server to JRun server communications (see http://cfprimer.blogspot.com/2005/03/tcpip-efficiency.html);
  3. If you can reproduce this, use a tool such as Ethereal to capture the communications around the time that things go bad, and send that trace file to us or Adobe Product Support (or both!) for analysis.

If you're seeing this issue for many or all threads, then these are the likely causes:

  1. You have "save class files" enabled in the ColdFusion Administrator
  2. Something is causing class files to be constantly recompiled

Things to try:

  1. Turn off "save class files" in the ColdFusion Administrator;
  2. Find out what is causing templates to be continuously recompiled and stop it! (Note that anything that resets timestamps on templates will force recompiles.)

methodinfo.description: Validating a CF tag while compiling a ColdFusion page

methodinfo.longdescription: The JRun Proxy Service is waiting for new TCP socket connections to come from the Web server. This is normal, and can be ignored.

The JRun Proxy Service is waiting for information about new page requests to come from the Web server. This is normal, and can usually be ignored. In rare cases, this may indicate a TCP communication problem between the Web server and JRun, if they are on different physical machines.

methodinfo.description: Writing completed page back to the Web server.
methodinfo.longdescription:
If you're seeing this issue for many or all threads, then these are the likely causes:

  1. You have many users downloading very large pages over very slow (dialup?) connections.
  2. Your internet connection is flooded.
  3. Something is misconfigured with your network.

Things to try:

  1. Enable response compression at the Web server.
  2. Ensure no networking devices are set to "autonegotiate"-- force speed/duplex settings for all devices
  3. Use a packet analyzer to determine if your response tcp window size is very small. If so, ensure that any response proxy servers or load balancers have a large enough response buffer.

If you're seeing this issue for many or all threads, then these are the likely causes:

  1. You have confgured too few request handler threads (eg, in the ColdFusion Administrator)

methodinfo.description: Calling a method on a Java object
This thread has been told to sleep for some time

methodinfo.longdescription: If you're seeing this issue for many or all threads, you're likely either streaming data over time, or you're pushing large amounts of data to poorly-connected or slow browsers.

methodinfo.description: Loading a class definition (or other file) using the Java classloader
methodinfo.longdescription: This is normally seen then the Java ClassLoader is loading a class definition, but can also be seen when loading another resource in the classpath, such as a properties file.

methodinfo.description: Running a query using the Query cfc
methodinfo.longdescription: This is normally seen then the Java ClassLoader is loading a class definition, but can also be seen when loading another resource in the classpath, such as a properties file.
This is a normal activity for most sites.
This is a normal activity for most sites.

methodinfo.description: Lucee is closing a database statement
methodinfo.longdescription: If this is happening a lot, check your queries to make sure they're not dealing with very large amounts of data.
If you're seeing this a lot for one query, make sure that query is properly indexed.

methodinfo.description: Lucee cfquery tag with cfqueryparam subtag(s)
methodinfo.longdescription: If you're seeing this a lot for one query, make sure that query is properly indexed.
